title: What is the partial derivative of x^3y -xy^3 with respect to x? - Quora

response.answer_text: The partial derivatives are generally denoted by ςΨ/ςχ ς. (x³y-xy³ )/ςx =y (say) Partial derivative of a Implicit function I,e a function of the form f(x,y)=c where 'c' is any real constant is denoted by fx and fy. Where fx is partial derivative of the function f only with respect to x and treating y as a constant. fx=y(3x²)-(1)y³ fx=3x²y-y³. Derivative of x^n is nx^(n-1)
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Gursanjan Singh Natt

response.answer_text: We have to find partial derivative of the given function with respect to X So every other variable will be treated as constant. This is the concept of Partial derivative… So let f(x,y)= x^3y - xy^3 1)  So partial derivative w.r.t x will be 3y•x^(3y-1) - y^3 (Note that y is treated as constant) If same is being Asked as partial derivative wrt y Now in this case x will be treated as constant So let f(x,y)=x^3y - xy^3 So partial derivative wrt y will be x^3y × ln(x) × 3 - x•3y^2 ( As derivative of a^y wrt y is a^y×ln(y)) 2) If the function is

Given equation: f(x,y)=x^3y-xy^3 So for partial derivative of f(x,y) with respect to x we have to kéep y constant Also vise a versa, for with respect to y keep x constant So, df(x,y)/dx=3y*x^(3y-1)-(1)*y^3 i.e. df(x,y)/dx=3y*x^(3y-1)-y^3
u=X^3y-xy^3 Partial derivative with respect to x du/dx = 3x^2y-y^3
